item.title: Software Architect 2007
item.description:
Last week I had the pleasure of spending a few days in London attending the Software Architect 2007 conference at the Barbican centre. It was a good conference, providing me with some useful and interesting new ideas and food for thought, whilst confirming that our team at Marshalls are generally going about things in ‚Äúthe right way‚Äù, which is nice.

Looking through my notes, the main themes that kept recurring within the different presentations that I attended were:

item.title: A C# Postcode Struct with Parser
item.description:
As discussed recently, I‚Äôve been trying to knock together a class struct to represent a UK postcode, provide a means of parsing a string as potentially being a valid postcode (or optionally just an outer code), and split that postcode into ‚Äúouter‚Äù and ‚Äúinner‚Äù code.

I say potentially because, as you‚Äôll know if you‚Äôve looked into this topic at all, it‚Äôs impossible to validate whether a string truly does represent a postcode without querying the (copyrighted and expensive-to-license) Postcode Address File. ¬†As a result, my solution is not very stringent ‚Äì it is possible to persuade it to successfully parse an invalid postcode, but hopefully there should be no occasions when a valid postcode is rejected.

item.title: Postcode Validation
item.description:
Wikipedia cracks me up sometimes. I‚Äôm sat here at my desk, trying to knock together some C# code to quickly validate an entered string as being a UK postcode. Naturally I turned to this Wikipedia article for assistance, where I find this quip:

“Automatic validation of postcodes on the basis of pattern feasibility is therefore almost impossible to design, and the system contains no self-validating feature such as a check digit. Completely accurate validation is only possible by attempting to deliver mail to the address, and verifying with the recipient.”

item.title: SQL 2005 Unleashed
item.description: Many moons (and about four jobs) ago, a wise DBA by the name of David Hanson once recommended to me a book called Microsoft SQL Server 2000 Unleashed. I took his advice, bought a copy, and it rapidly became one of the most dog-eared and oft-thumbed computing books I have ever owned. It is comprehensive, deep, broad, well-written and covers everything one might ever wish to know about SQL Server 2000. With its help and guidance I came to love and respect Microsoft‚Äôs premier database product, passing the 70-229 exam by a comfortable margin.

item.title: MSDN Technical Roadshow 2007
item.description: I‚Äôm off to the MSDN Technical roadshow in Harrogate tomorrow, and am actually really looking forward to it this time. These events are free, so always well worth attending when they‚Äôre local, but some years are certainly better than others ‚Äì it mostly depends on the material being covered. I remember one year circa 2003-4, when .NET was well established, but before the Whidbey release, so the majority of the day was effectively just a sales pitch covering elementary .NET concepts, presumably for those laggards who hadn‚Äôt yet made the great leap from VB6. Another data-binding demo, anybody?¬† Yawn.

item.title: More Tufte Books
item.description: When I mentioned Edward R. Tufte‚Äôs excellent The Visual Display of Quantitative Information in a recent blog post, it prompted me to search North Yorkshire‚Äôs online library catalogue to see if they had any more of the great man‚Äôs works. I was delighted to find that both Envisioning Information and Visual Explanations were available, yet languishing in a storage room somewhere rather than being on the shelves of one of the county‚Äôs libraries! ¬†So, I placed a request and they turned up at my local branch a few days later.

item.title: Spot The Misleading Graph
item.description:
Fifty-three years since Darrell Huff published the seminal How to Lie with Statistics, and still we have newspapers as august as The Times pulling the oldest trick in the book:

At first glance it all looks very impressive, but closer inspection of the comparison with sales of the Torygraph reveal a mere 8.7% sales lead, not more than double as suggested by the graphic.¬† Not fooled.

item.title: Dangling Off A Skyscraper
item.description:
I keep intending, and forgetting to post a couple of videos from our US holiday last April. ¬†I suppose I was hoping to get round to writing up my paper notes from the holiday, but it‚Äôs becoming apparent that won‚Äôt happen anytime soon, so let‚Äôs skip forward to the funny bits:

We spent a couple of nights at the Stratosphere Hotel in Las Vegas, which is the tallest observation tower in the United States. ¬†Atop the tower are three ‚Äúthrill rides‚Äù, and I foolishly tried all of them whilst Jocelyn videoed proceedings from a safe distance.

item.title: Ian Nelson, MCSD.Net
item.description:
I am now a Microsoft Certified Solution Developer in .NET 1.x technologies. This is a qualification that I‚Äôve been working towards on and (more often than not) off for the past four years or so. It‚Äôs not really the case that the exams were super-hard, just that it took occasional motivation to get round to taking them!

So, was it worth it?¬† Did I learn anything en route?¬† Did the exams boost my employability?¬† Would I be more inclined to employ someone with an MCSD than an applicant without?

item.title: For Our Tomorrows
item.description:
On this Remembrance Sunday, permit me to share with you a photo that my cousin Helen took this week of our Granduncle‚Äôs grave in France.

Private William Henry Worfolk (1896 ‚Äì 1916) of the York and Lancaster Regiment was my Grandfather‚Äôs elder brother (by four years), and was only just old enough to fight (and die) in the First World War. ¬†A couple of years later and it could just as easily have been my grandfather, and then I wouldn‚Äôt be here to tell you this tale. ¬†Ninety years on from that most bloody of wars, we still have much to be thankful for.

item.title: A Genealogical Milestone
item.description:
Late last night I reached a small but significant milestone in my family tree research:¬† I now know the names of my sixteen great-great-grandparents!¬† Or so I believe ‚Äì I just need to wait for a couple of certificates to arrive from the GRO to prove my theories.

So, who do I think I am?¬† Well, at this stage it appears that my blood is:

  • 50.0% English
  • 37.5% Scottish
  • 12.5% Irish

Those sixteen ancestors were born between 1829 and 1860.

item.title: Genealogy ‚Äì My New Winter Hobby
item.description:
‚ÄúINTPs are always so mentally active that they continually delve into new interests‚Ä¶ The interests of an INTP would be enough to occupy him for several lifetimes if that were possible.‚Äù

‚Äî A description of the INTP personality type, Paul James.

I‚Äôve been in need of a new hobby for a while now. ¬†The mental challenges offered from getting married, changing jobs and moving home have passed, and my free evenings and weekends were becoming prone to bouts of restlessness and sighs of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm bored‚Äù. ¬†This is not a good thing.

item.title: A Serializable KeyValuePair Class
item.description: Having accepted that Returning DataSets from WebServices is the Spawn of Satan and Represents All That Is Truly Evil in the World (or at least, not exactly best practice), I‚Äôve been trying to make a conscious effort to instead use lightweight custom objects in my middle tier, to be exposed via web services for use by other applications. I felt sure that some of the new Generic classes in the .NET 2.0 FCL would help me in my quest. Specifically, as I often need to expose simple arrays of Key/Value Pair metadata, I planned to create an instance of the¬† System.Collections.ObjectModel.Collection class, containing a bunch of System.Collections.Generic.KeyValuePair objects.¬†

item.title: Big Integer
item.description:
As I mentioned last summer, I do enjoy whiling away a few hours attempting to solve the maths / progamming challenges set on Project Euler. My language of choice for most puzzles is C#, but this hampered me on some of the questions as there is no in-built support for really big integers.

However, a little bit of Googling and I came across this excellent BigInteger class on Code Project which does everything I need and more ‚Äì and it seems bloody fast, too. Thanks to this class, I‚Äôve been able to knock off several more problems this weekend, and now have a rating of ‚Äú11% Genius‚Äù ‚Äì still some way to go, then‚Ä¶

item.title: Jury Service
item.description:
I‚Äôve recently completed a stint of jury service, which lasted a little over two weeks at York Crown Court. For obvious reasons, I can‚Äôt blog about the trials I was involved with, but it was a fascinating couple of weeks, and it would be a shame not to share some of the experience with you.

Whenever I mentioned my upcoming service to friends and colleagues, their responses fell into one of two camps: either, ‚ÄúUgh, I‚Äôd hate that! I‚Äôd really dread doing jury service!‚Äù or, ‚ÄúYou lucky sod, I‚Äôd love to do that, but I‚Äôve never been asked!‚Äù The thought of serving on a jury clearly polarises people, and I must confess, I felt a certain dread when I first received my summons.

item.title: USA Trip 2006: Breakfast Prep
item.description:
On our first morning in California, we headed out to breakfast, which was preceded by a short session of Breakfast Prep‚Äô, courtesy of Jocelyn.¬† It had been a couple of years since I‚Äôd last had Breakfast In America, and I‚Äôd forgotten how to respond to the awesome number of choices and options that would be flung in my direction by the waitperson.

Here‚Äôs how you order breakfast in Britain:

  <td>
    “<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_English_Breakfast">Full English Breakfast</a>, please.”
  </td>
</tr>

<tr>
  <td>
    Waitress:
  </td>
  
  <td>
    “D‚Äôyou want tea or coffee with that?”
  </td>
</tr>

<tr>
  <td>
    Diner:
  </td>
  
  <td>
    “Tea, please.”
  </td>
</tr>

<tr>
  <td>
    Waitress:
  </td>
  
  <td>
    “OK.”
  </td>
</tr>

In due course, the standard, empire-forging breakfast is served, and is consumed heartily, perhaps after a little trading with your breakfasting companions (‚ÄúI‚Äôll swap you my tomatoes for a rasher of your bacon?‚Äù).¬† Everybody knows what is expected, nobody has tricky decisions to make, there are no surprises, and everyone enjoys what they get ‚Äì and if they don‚Äôt enjoy it, well, they don‚Äôt mention it, because complaining about such things just wouldn‚Äôt be British, damn it.

item.title: USA Trip 2006: Arrival
item.description:
Monday 10th April 2006

The sun was still shining as we touched down at SFO, about 22 hours after we‚Äôd woken up.¬† If every day could last that long, I swear I‚Äôd get more work done ‚Äì or maybe I‚Äôd just spend more time playing Civilization‚Ä¶

We picked up the car ‚Äì a Pontiac Impala which initially seemed unfeasibly huge compared to our Focus, but it‚Äôs funny how quickly you adjust and get used to the size, making use of the available space ‚Äì then it was off down US 101 on the final leg of our journey.¬† Despite it being rush hour, we had a swift journey due to being able to use the Car Pool lane (by virtue of not being a single-occupant vehicle).¬† I was amazed how under-utilised this lane was, and started wondering how much of an incentive would be needed for more Bay area commuters to start sharing rides ‚Äì there‚Äôs another good question for the economists to ponder.

item.title: USA Trip 2006: Journey
item.description:
_Monday 10th April 2006

Travelling West during the daytime is a blast, especially on a sunny day.¬† Time it right and you can experience daylight for 24 hours, which afforded me time to catch up on some reading.¬† For Christmas Joce had given a book entitled Freakonomics ‚Äì A Rogue Economist Explores The Hidden Side Of Eveything, and now I finally had time to read through it.¬† I surprised myself by finishing it by the time we reached Chicago ‚Äì this may be a chunky hardback book on economics, but it‚Äôs also really interesting and easy-going.

item.title: USA Trip 2006: Departure
item.description:
Last month Jocelyn and I took a trip to the States to visit friends and family, attend Teri & Jimmy‚Äôs wedding, and take a vacation to Nevada and Arizona.

So, there we were, sitting at the departure gate at Manchester Airport on a bright Monday morning, having awoken at 0430 to make our way across the Pennines.¬† A few seats away were a group of teenagers.¬† They were from Michigan, and they were annoyingly noisy.¬† Thus began our American adventure.

item.title: Universal Comparer for .NET
item.description: Back in November 2004, I had the idea of making a “Generic Sorter for Strongly-Typed Collections”, by harnessing the mighty power of reflection. Well, earlier this month somebody anonymously emailed me some code that takes this to a whole different level, enabling sorting on multiple properties and to arbitrary depths within the domain model hierarchy, all by taking a single SQL-like parameter. It‚Äôs really very clever indeed, and I‚Äôm going to use this method in the future ‚Äì thanks, anonymous code fairy!

item.title: String.IsNullOrEmpty
item.description:
The single most popular entry on this blog is, surprisingly enough, this quick post from Summer 2004 where I did a quick experiment to “prove” that in .NET the quickest way of proving that a string is empty is to compare its length to zero.

Well, as of .NET 2.0, we have a new static method on the System.String class ‚Äì IsNullOrEmpty ‚Äì that allows you to easily test whether a string is, well, null or empty!

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Twenty-Four
item.description: Hertog Jan Doppio Double is the only one of my twenty-four Advent beers to come in a stone cork-stoppered bottle that weighs more than the drink contained within! At 7.3% ABV, it‚Äôs also the second-strongest drink in my selection, and hence has a real kick to it.¬† That said, it also has a gorgeous malty aroma, and strong aftertaste which beer lovers will appreciate.¬† So whilst it‚Äôs not quite my personal favourite of the twenty-four beers I‚Äôve had the pleasure of sampling this yuletide, it‚Äôs certainly an appropriately worthy and warming drink on which to finish.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Twenty-Three
item.description: The penultimate beer on my 2005 advent calendar was Ruby Red from the St. Peter‚Äôs Brewery in Suffolk. ¬†I‚Äôd been looking forward to this 4.3% ABV red ale, which, like all of the beers from St. Peter‚Äôs, comes in a distinctive flask-shaped oval bottle, so I was somewhat disappointed by the intense bitterness of the first few mouthfuls. ¬†However, I think this was mostly due to the effects of the Mexican dinner laced with Encona sauces that I‚Äôd scoffed a few minutes previously. ¬†Further into the bottle, the ‚Äúsubtle malt undertones and spicy aroma‚Äù became more apparent, and overall I really enjoyed this beer ‚Äì I‚Äôll definitely be trying some of the others from the range.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Twenty-Two
item.description: Fraoch is a 5% ABV Scottish beer that brings back many happy memories of late nights spent in the bar at the Clachaig Inn. ¬†‚ÄúFraoch‚Äù is the Gaelic for heather, so take a guess what this beer is made from? ¬†If you‚Äôve never tried it, that might sound a bit weird, but believe me that this is a great beer with ‚Äúa floral, peaty aroma, full malt body, spicy herbal flavour and a dry wine like finish‚Äù. ¬†What more could you ask for? ¬†Slainte!

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Twenty-One
item.description:
‚ÄúJingle Knockers‚Äù isn‚Äôt exactly a phrase that inspires confidence, but this 5.5% ABV from Skinner‚Äôs Brewery in Cornwall is really good, definitely on a par with the stuff I‚Äôve tried from Hambleton Ales and the Harviestoun Brewery. ¬†Smooth and strong, with subtle hints of Christmas pud ‚Äì mmmm‚Ä¶

Oh, and if you‚Äôre still confused by that name, the label handily explains all:

‚ÄúKnown as the Tin Mine Fairies, the Cornish Knockers used to guide the miners to the rich veins of ore by knocking. ¬†With the demise of mining over the years, many knockers have ;returned to grass‚Äô where, in disguise, they help with the brewing of their ales.‚Äù

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Twenty
item.description: Now, don‚Äôt get me wrong, there are many great things that have originated from America ‚Äì not least of all my good lady wife ‚Äì but I‚Äôve always thought that ‚ÄúAmerican Beer‚Äù is something of an anachronism! ¬†Let‚Äôs face it, most beers from across the Altlantic are sorely lacking in flavour, body, bitterness, or, well, anything remotely beerlike. ¬†So, whilst on my search for twenty-four bottled beers for this advent calendar, I was intrigued to find Honker‚Äôs Ale from the Goose Island Beer Company in Chicago which describes itself as ‚Äúa smooth, drinkable English bitter for those drinkers who want more from their beer‚Äù. ¬†Well, let‚Äôs hope they‚Äôre not looking for too much more, as it only comes in a 355ml bottle. ¬†It tastes OK when compared to the likes of Budweiser and Samuel Adams, but it‚Äôs not exactly bold or challenging, and the whole experience was over far too quickly. ¬†Not exactly one to savour on a cold winter‚Äôs night in Yorkshire, but I can imagine these going down quite well in the sports stadia of Iliinois.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Nineteen
item.description:
Smuggler‚Äôs Ale is another bottled beer which found its way into my calendar via an Asda beer competition. ¬†It‚Äôs 5% ABV, with hints of treacle, and is really rather enjoyable.

And to paraphrase Forrest Gump, that‚Äôs all I have to say about that. ¬†Back to my beer and a DVD of Family Guy.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Eighteen
item.description:
There‚Äôs something a wee bit disappointing about picking up a bottle labelled ‚ÄúMOROCCO ALE‚Äù and finding that it is, in fact, from nowhere more distant than Harrogate ‚Äì the Daleside Brewery to be precise. ¬†According to the label:

‚ÄúThe recipe for Morocco Ale is believed to date from Elizabethan times. ¬†Colonel John Grahme of Levens was a courtier to James II and the name ‚ÄòMorocco‚Äô may have been associated with the dark Moors who came to the court when Catherine of Braganza married Charles II and brought Tangiers as part of her dowry.‚Äù

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Days Sixteen And Seventeen
item.description:
Friday night saw me out celebrating in Halifax at our departmental Christmas meal (FWIW, I drank a few pints of Santa‚Äôs Little Helper from the Caledonian brewery). ¬†As a result, I didn‚Äôt get chance to enjoy my advent beer, and have been playing catch-up with a couple of randomly-selected bottles tonight.

Firstly, the sixteenth beer to be selected from the vase of fate was Delirium Nocturnum, a 9.0% ABV dark ale from the Huyghe-Melle brewery in Belgium which comes in silver glittery 330ml bottles featuring pictures of pink elephants. ¬†I was somewhat apprehensive, but needlessly so, as this is a surprisingly well-balanced and hoppy triply-fermented ale ‚Äì not a novelty drink at all (despite the packaging being somewhat reminiscent of a Pizza Express salad dressing bottle).

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Days Thirteen, Fourteen and Fifteen!
item.description:
Gadzooks! ¬†Who would have thought that it would be so difficult to find a few minutes each day to transcribe a few words about a bottle of beer? ¬†But it is ‚Äì especially as we enter the party season and my evenings are filled with festivities.

The good news is, I have three excellent beers to report on; the first two of which are from breweries that I‚Äôve already ‚Äúvisited‚Äù during this advent calendar.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Twelve
item.description: Halfway through my great beer advent calendar 2005, and tonight I‚Äôve enjoyed the popular Leffe Blonde, a potent and delicious 6.6% ABV beer from Belgium. ¬†I‚Äôve been meaning to try this reknowned tipple since I utterly failed to identify a snippet of the label in one of those irritating Excel-based quizzes that circulates on the interweb periodically. ¬†Anyway, I wasn‚Äôt disappointed ‚Äì the small bottle size (33cl) being more than made up for by the strength and the flavour (quite almondy, I thought). ¬†There‚Äôs a good detailed review by someone with more effective taste buds than I over at the excellent Oxford Bottled Beer Database.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Eleven
item.description:
I just realised that I forgot to blog about yesterday‚Äôs advent beer. ¬†Sorry for keeping you all on tenterhooks like that!

To be honest I was a bit disappointed and couldn‚Äôt think of anything interesting to say about Rudolph‚Äôs Revenge, a 4.6% ABV bitter from Cropton Brewery. ¬†It was quite similar to the equally uninspiring Mars Magic from last Thursday.

item.title: John's Background Switcher
item.description:
What‚Äôs on your desktop background?¬† Some bland corporate logo perhaps, or maybe one of the bog-standard Windows wallpapers, or maybe a photograph you took years ago?
Let‚Äôs face it, when was the last time you changed your background?¬† Wouldn‚Äôt it be great if you could specify a few keywords and have your background periodically change to show a new image courtesy of Flickr?¬† Say, a sunrise, a mountain, a wintry scene, a favourite holiday destination, or, well, whatever takes your fancy?

item.title: ASP.NET 2.0 ‚Äì one month on
item.description: It‚Äôs over a month now since Visual Studio 2005 officially RTM‚Äôd, and during that time I‚Äôve been fortunate enough to have been using it for the majority of my time on most working days. One of the things we‚Äôre trying to achieve is the integration of several distinct internal corporate web applications into a bespoke portal system, with single sign-on, common authorization model, common look and feel, etc. There‚Äôs been quite a heavy R&D / proof-of-concept aspect to the workload so far, as we try out different ways of achieving this, and grow familiar with the new technologies available to us in ASP.NET 2.0.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Ten
item.description: Ah, I do enjoy beers by the Wychwood Brewery, who have a particularly good website (i.e. better than most of the brewery sites I‚Äôve come across so far). ¬†Hobgoblin is an obvious favourite, easily available from any supermarket worth its salt. ¬†Today I sampled their Whirlygig ale, a 4.5% ‚Äúfrenzy of hops and malt‚Äù, which really is delicious. ¬†Lots of flavour, lots of character ‚Äì very enjoyable indeed. ¬†This one goes into the ‚Äúbuy again‚Äù column. ¬†Jocelyn didn‚Äôt get a look in, so I can‚Äôt give you the female opinion, sorry.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Nine
item.description: Rosey Nosey by Bateman‚Äôs Brewery has a deceptively cutesy name, but it turns out to be a really decent-quality ale with plenty of flavour and a pleasing warmth. If you have to buy one festive-themed beer this year, you could do much worse than this one.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Eight
item.description:
Another day, another beer. ¬†It‚Äôs a hard life. ¬†Mars Magic is a rather unexciting 4.6% ABV ‚ÄúPremium Ale‚Äù (it says here) from the Wold Top Brewery. ¬†Noticeably lacking in anything resembling a head, it did however seem to improve as I progressed through the half-litre (funny how that happens). ¬†So, with my whistle well and truly whetted, I‚Äôm off down the pub. ¬†Cya!

Oh, I nearly forgot to record Joce‚Äôs comments on the bitter. ¬†It went something like: ‚ÄúEurgh!‚Äù

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Seven
item.description: Wednesday night‚Äôs tipple was the rather strange 5% ABV Kronenbourg Blanc, from UK brewing giant Scottish & Newcastle. ¬†Described as a ‚Äúrefreshing, fruity white beer‚Äù, this is in fact blatantly piss-coloured (which probably explains why it comes in an opaque bottle). ¬†I found this to be more reminiscent of a weak cider or some kind of bizarre citrus alcopop than anything deserving to have the word ‚Äúbeer‚Äù on the label. ¬†Still, try everything once except Morris Dancing and incest, as the saying goes.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Six
item.description: A return to form today, with the vase of fate serving up a helping of Riggwelter, the Black Sheep Brewery‚Äôs delicious 4.7% strong Yorkshire ale. ¬†I could drink this till the cows come home. ¬†Or perhaps that should be the sheep, for (according to the bottle) the name Riggwelter comes from the Old Norse rygg meaning to overturn. ¬†‚ÄúWhen a sheep is on its back and cannot get up without help, local dales dialect says it‚Äôs rigged or riggwelted.‚Äù

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Five
item.description:
Today‚Äôs festive ale is the Teignworthy Christmas Cracker, a strong (6% ABV) dark and warming malty bottle conditioned ale from deepest Devon.

Um, it‚Äôs OK, certainly tastes weighty and, well, worthy, but it isn‚Äôt really to my taste ‚Äì it has a very strong aftertaste yet is lacking in any interesting fruity flavours.¬†¬†There are plenty of other things I‚Äôd rather drink before picking this.

Jocelyn says: ‚ÄúDamn, I‚Äôve dripped it on my top, I‚Äôll have to wash this now.‚Äù

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Four
item.description: Another superb ale tonight, and this one is close to home.¬†Nightmare¬†by the Hambleton Ales microbrewery in Thirsk is an extremely creamy, fruity, and flavoursome stout‚Äînot as bitter as you might expect from its appearance. Very tasty‚ÄîI‚Äôll definitely be buying this again.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Three
item.description:
Third Time Lucky!

After two days of novelty nonsense, the vase of fate finally served up a half-litre of Harviestoun Brewery‚Äôs 4.8% masterpiece,¬†Schiehallion, named after my all-time favourite Munro.

Here‚Äôs an interesting fact for you: the mass of the Earth was first measured in 1774 when the Astronomer Royal, one Nevil Maskelyne, spent four months mucking about on Schiehallion with pendulums. By observing how the mountain‚Äôs bulk caused the pendulums (pendula?) to swing away from the vertical, he was able to estimate the mountain‚Äôs mass and extrapolate from this to calculate our planet‚Äôs mass at 5,000 million million tonnes‚Äîwhich is a pretty reasonable estimate, if you ask me. Based on that work, it then became possible to determine the mass of all the other planets, their moons, and even the Sun itself. All of which rather puts my own summer‚Äôs evening stroll up Schiehallion in 1998 into perspective, enjoyable though it was.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day Two
item.description:
Well, this evening‚Äôs advent beer couldn‚Äôt be more different from yesterday‚Äôs. I had the dubious pleasure of sampling¬†Crazy Ed‚Äôs Cave Creek Chili Beer, all the way from Arizona.

Be warned: the website dates from 1999, and boy, does it show‚Äîwe‚Äôre talking Comic Sans in a scrolling¬†¬†tag, framesets that have a tendency to get confused (try clicking the ‚Äúhome‚Äù link), and a 53-kilopixel JPEG weighing in at an astonishing 232 KB (why?!). Seeing those ‚ÄúNetscape Now!‚Äù animated GIFs makes me all nostalgic for the twentieth century‚Ä¶

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar ‚Äì Day One
item.description:
This is surely one of the best ideas I‚Äôve ever had! I‚Äôve followed through with my plan to buy twenty-four beers from around the world to count down the days until Christmas. Their names are all written on slips of folded paper in a small vase (nobody actually draws things out of a hat anymore, do they?).

Today I‚Äôm enjoying¬†Young‚Äôs Christmas Pudding Ale, which is 5.5% ABV according to the bottle but only 5.0% according to the website‚Äîdon‚Äôt believe everything you read on the web, eh?

item.title: Rounding Up The Result of Integer Division
item.description:
Here‚Äôs a damn useful piece of information which should be in the armoury of every modern codemonkey:

I‚Äôve used this deliciously elegant result in production J2EE code in the past, but it‚Äôs equally valid in C#, as long as you can make the additional assertion that m/n is positive. This is because whilst Java treats integer division by rounding to zero, C# merely truncates the result (in an unchecked context). In my experience, the most frequentuse for this result is the deft answering of questions such as ‚Äúif I have x items in my dataset and I display y per page, how many pages do I have in total?‚Äù, where it is obviously safe to make the assertion of a positive result.

item.title: 10 Things That Should Be More Popular
item.description:
Some days I feel like I‚Äôm spitting in the wind. It amazes me that the following ten concepts, websites and applications aren‚Äôt more widely used:

  1. RSS Feeds ‚Äì why waste your time repeatedly trawling dozens of sites looking for new content?¬† Let it come to you!
  2. Flickr ‚Äì practically everyone I know has a digital camera, but still relatively few have a Flickr account. Share your photos, don‚Äôt keep them unseen on your hard drive!
  3. GMail ‚Äì by far the most effective web-based email.
  4. FireFox ‚Äì if only for the tabbed browsing. But really, it‚Äôs so much nicer than IE6, and a myriad of different extensions are available.
  5. OneNote ‚Äì so much better than scraps of paper.
  6. Desktop Search ‚Äì I don‚Äôt care which desktop search program you use, but please install one!¬† You‚Äôll find it so much easier to find old emails and other files.
  7. del.icio.us ‚Äì access your bookmarks anywhere, and share them with friends.
  8. ClearType ‚Äì if you have a flatscreen monitor, you should turn ClearType on. Period.
  9. Virtual PC ‚Äì there‚Äôs no need to test beta software on your main machine, or keep several differently-configured computers around the house any more!
  10. SyncToy ‚Äì this is a great little app for synchronizing and backing-up folders; it‚Äôs really useful for combining media folders, and for synching files with a portable hard drive.

item.title: Computer Games I Have Loved
item.description:
Isn‚Äôt it funny how one‚Äôs tastes change as maturity progresses? ¬†I used to spend my summer holidays at the sea-side, playing in arcades and seeking the perfect milkshake (lime); more recently I‚Äôve been spending them in the highlands, playing on the hills and seeking the perfect dram (lagavulin). ¬†Hmmm‚Ä¶

I think I may have mentioned that the wife is away in the States for a while. ¬†At the start of this period of solitude, I panicked, wondering whatever I could do with myself, and came to the conclusion that it would be a good idea to buy a computer game to while away the hours. ¬†After all, I spent much of my formative years killing time on a variety of computer and console games, so why not rekindle that prior love affair? ¬†So it was that I bought The Sims 2, a truly excellent game, and had an enjoyable evening trying to motivate my wee Sims to improve their skills, better themselves, and generally enjoy life. ¬†All good harmless fun.

item.title: Project Euler
item.description: If you like maths problems, and you like programming (and hey, who doesn‚Äôt?), then you‚Äôll love Project Euler.

item.title: Aussie Apostle Claimed By Sea
item.description: Holy cow, one of the limestone towers at Australia‚Äôs Twelve Apostles park has collapsed into the sea! ¬†It was the one in the foreground of the photo to the left. Seeing this fantastic set of rock formations (and flying over them in a helicopter) was one of the many highlights of my vacation to Australia in Dec 2002 / Jan 2003. ¬†You always hear about coastal erosion and the way landscape changes over time, but never really expect significant changes to occur during your own lifetime‚Ä¶

item.title: Stopwatch Class for .NET 1.1
item.description:
Paul Welter has backported the System.Diagnostics.Stopwatch class from .NET 2.0 to 1.1. Handy.

http://weblogs.asp.net/pwelter34/archive/2005/07/01/416999.aspx

item.title: New Recommendations for String Comparisons in .NET 2.0
item.description: I know it‚Äôs a rather geeky and dry subject, but I found this MSDN article on new recommendations for using strings in .NET 2.0 quite interesting. It‚Äôs going to be difficult to stop using CultureInfo.InvariantCulture habitually!

item.title: eXtreme .NET
item.description: Up at 0500 yesterday and onto the early GNER Mallard down to that¬†London town for the MSDN briefing on eXtreme programming with .NET. It was pleasant not to be driving for a change, and speeding through the Yorkshire countryside early on a midsummer morning was very relaxing ‚Äì what a stark contrast with the hot crowded tube that I had to catch on arrival to the big smoke. Three stops down to Oxford Circus seemed to last as long as the entire preceeding train journey. How people do this every single day I do not know..

item.title: Tech Books
item.description:
I succumbed to temptation and bought another book at the MSDN briefing yesterday, pausing only out of concern that the guy who mans the Computer Manuals stand at these events might think that I‚Äôm stalking him (or fancy him!). Having determined that I could hand over my Barclaycard whilst flashing my wedding ring, I brought my current reading list up to three:

Developer to Designer: GUI Design for the Busy Developer ‚Äì this was a wedding present from my mother-in-law and is proving to be an interesting, easy-going read so far. My competencies lie in the middle tier and database, and although I‚Äôm technically capable of making GUIs, I prefer to leave the design up to others. It‚Äôs inevitable though that most coders end up doing some design, and this book is, er, designed (sorry) to help with that process. The early section of the book concentrates on each UI element in turn, whilst the later part of the book looks at putting it all together, and has particular focus on the web ‚Äì layout design patterns and interaction patterns. It‚Äôs a good read, making a nice contrast from the heavier books, and I‚Äôm pleased to learn that I‚Äôm not alone in hating Outlook‚Äôs labyrinthine Tools->Options dialog!

item.title: Software Development Books
item.description: Elizabeth Keogh has been blogging her advice for software-developer apprentices, and recommends buying and reading a selection of good software development books. I think this is sound advice ‚Äì personally I felt that my career and abilities starting taking off when I stopped reading tech-specific Wrox tomes that were obsolete within six months of publication and started buying timeless Addison-Wesley hardbacks. Why so many newbie coders insist on rediscovering solutions to well-known problems instead of leveraging the knowledge of our programming forebears is beyond me, but most of us have behaved in this way at some point. Give yourself a leg-up and read some decent software design books.

item.title: Framework for Persisting .NET Classes Into SQL Server Image Fields, With Locking Ability
item.description:
There seems to have been a lack of .NET-related stuff on this blog recently, so let me show you something I cobbled together for work purposes last Wednesday:

A common requirement we have in our ASP.NET applications is how to reliably persist object instances¬†for a lengthy period of time. End users shouldn‚Äôt have to concern themselves with the concept of Session expiry, and it‚Äôs unacceptable for them to return to their PC after nipping off for a coffee to be confronted with the dreaded “Object reference not set to an instance of an object” when they try to continue editing their basket / sales order / timesheet / whatever.

Never underestimate the stupidity of users‚Äîor the benefits of a little field validation.

One of the web-based systems I‚Äôve been developing allows users to enter a customer‚Äôs fax number and automatically fax confirmation details (using Zetafax). It‚Äôs been working pretty well‚Äîuntil we discovered a flaw today. One user, tired of obtaining valid fax details from customers, had been entering a string of nines and then actually attempting to send the fax to this number.

item.title: SQL Server Best Practices Analyser Tool
item.description: Via Eric G. Harrison ‚Äì MS have developed a SQL Server Best Practices Analyser Tool. It‚Äôs like a cross between FxCop and Baseline Security Analyser, for SQL Server. Very useful. I just downloaded it, ran it against some of my databases, and it made some useful suggestions. This could quickly become indispensable.

item.title: Property Access Modifiers in Whidbey
item.description:
Ooh, this is great news:

http://nxopinion.robertsoninstitute.org/blogs/rcecil/archive/2004/11/11/167.aspx

It‚Äôs a little thing, to be sure, but I often find myself wanting to make a setter internal or private while leaving the getter public. So, I‚Äôm happy. It doesn‚Äôt take much üôÇ

item.title: I‚Äôm an MCAD!
item.description: Woohoo!¬† I just passed MS exam 70-320 with a score of 936, and am now a Microsoft Certified Application Developer!

item.title: A Generic Sorter For Strongly-Typed Collections
item.description: Late last night I was doing some development work on a website for our investment club. I had a strongly-typed collection of “Stock” objects, and wanted to be able to sort them on any parameter (StockName, SharePrice, Volume, MarketCap, etc..) in either descending or ascending order. I didn‚Äôt want to have to write a separate comparer for each property. Reflection to the rescue! Below is a GenericSorter class, the use of which allows for the development of a Sort() method on the collection taking as a parameter the name of the property on which to sort. Smart.

item.title: NHibernate
item.description: There‚Äôs so much good open-source .Net development going on these days ‚Äì .Text, nGallery, nUnit, etc¬†‚Äì it‚Äôs a really interesting time to be a developer. My colleague Colin just drew my attention to nHibernate, an object persistence library for relational databases. TheServerSide.net has an excellent article summarising its use. Having just finished a long project where a large amount of time was spent writing ‚Äúplumbing‚Äù code to persist objects to and from a SQL Server database, I‚Äôm finding the idea of using an O/R mapper such as this very appealing the next time round. Just as incorporating the MS DAAB block into solutions has reduced the amount of data access code required, I‚Äôm hopeful that embracing frameworks such as nHibernate will leave us with more time to spend focusing on addressing the business needs and less on re-solving technical issues.

item.title: Ideal World / Real World
item.description:
A major project I‚Äôve been working on for the last ten months has just gone live, giving me some time recently to take stock, do a bit of R&D, and catch up on some reading. I‚Äôve been reflecting on how to approach things better in the future, and to this end, I‚Äôve just finished two very different books about the software development process.

O‚ÄôReilly‚Äôs¬†Extreme Programming Pocket Guide¬†is a handy little summary of the approach (only 81 pages), depicting a near-utopian development shop where everyone is happy, and projects come in under budget and on time. It got me quite fired up, actually, and some of the concepts described are interesting. But deep down, I just know this would never happen in the real world‚Äîtoo much politics, too many personalities at play in the workplace, in my humble opinion.

item.title: Is My String Empty? Some C# Performance Metrics
item.description:
Update (25/02/2006) ‚Äì Hey, we now have String.IsNullOrEmpty, you know!

What‚Äôs the quickest way, in C#, to test whether a string is empty?¬† This is a question which came to my mind yesterday. I‚Äôve always been fond of:

but it occured to me that this necessitates the creation and destruction of a second object (the empty string with which we‚Äôre comparing), so maybe it would be quicker to write:

item.title: Inheriting From BaseValidator to Make Custom Validation Controls
item.description:
For months now, I‚Äôve been desperate for a decent excuse to make a custom ASP.NET server control, so I was secretly pleased today when a CustomValidator originally coded for use on a single page was required elsewhere.

It‚Äôs surprisingly easy to do, although it took me a while to find a decent example online, which eventually came courtesy of the 4GuysFromRolla. In my particular scenario, I needed to check that the text entered into a TextBox did not equal any of a selection of “banned” strings (which was available via a static property on another class).

item.description:

A cloudy start at low heights, but as we ascended higher we broke through a cloud inversion, being presented with stunning blue skies and incredible views across to Ben Nevis and the Carn Mor Dearg arete.

item.title: Four Big Cairngorms
item.description:
Four big ones in the bag, thanks to an overnight stay at Corrour Bothy:

  • Braeriach (1296m)
  • The Devil‚Äôs Point (Bod an Deamhain) (1004m)
  • Cairn Toul (1291m)
  • Sgor an Lochain Uaine (1258m)

It was at some point on this day that my Nokia 5510, won during last year‚Äôs Nokia Game, got wet and died.

item.title: Ben Alder
item.description:
May Day weekend 2000. A late dash to Scotland after work on the Friday. A long and dark post-midnight walk to the Ben Alder cottage bothy. A cracking day in the hills on the Saturday, begging Beinn Bheoil (1019m) and Ben Alder (1148m) as part of The Great Scottish Climb charity event.

item.title: The Aonach Eagach Ridge
item.description:

  <img decoding="async" src="https://cdn.iannelson.uk/uploads/2023/08/2013_03_04_22_29_19.jpg" width="1496" height="2075" loading="lazy" alt srcset="https://cdn.iannelson.uk/uploads/2023/08/1_2013_03_04_22_29_19.jpg 600w, https://cdn.iannelson.uk/uploads/2023/08/2_2013_03_04_22_29_19.jpg 1000w, https://cdn.iannelson.uk/uploads/2023/08/2013_03_04_22_29_19.jpg 1496w" sizes="auto, (min-width: 720px) 720px" />

item.title: Mauling
item.description:
‚ÄúYou seem to be going awfully fast,‚Äù said the perspiring southern lady on the footpath to Stac Pollaidh, ‚Äúwould you pull me up?‚Äù

I smiled politely, but in reality I was both shocked and pleased to have realised that over the course of the week, my mental and physical fitness had increased, and here I was, alone, practically jogging towards the impressive sight that is Stac Pollaidh.

item.title: No Such Deviations
item.description: I first wandered up the long track toward Beinn Dearg a year ago, when Daffy insisted we leave it at an early stage and clamber up through snow-covered heather onto a large rounded ridge which seemed to go on forever before finally nearing the summit of Eididh nan Clach Geala. Fortunately no such deviations were ordered this year, which was just as well since I was on strangely good form viz-a-viz walking, and enjoyed setting a pace up the stream-crossed path until it eventually disappeared, at which point I reverted to my more familiar snail‚Äôs pace.

item.title: Soggy Foothills
item.description: Sunday a handful of us bagged Ben Wyvis, where apparently Martin Moran was avalanched during his record breaking winter munro expedition. ¬†Our trip up to the top was thankfully less life-threatening, with the only dangers coming from the many snowball fights, or riding over rocks during the pitifully slow bum-slide back to the soggy foothills. ¬†But the sun was out in force, as were the views. ¬†It was a good start to the holiday proper, and served as a gentle reminder how unfit I am, as I soon found myself lagging behind all and sundry during the ascent.

item.title: Vast Solid Pillar
item.description: Boy, do I let myself in for some exhausting pastimes. I could have spent the day at home, slumped in front of the web, but nope, not today. Gulvain is a right royal pain. A ‚Äúshy hill‚Äù, according to the books, which basically means you have to walk for miles before you reach its foot. Then you have a steep walk upwards before reaching what, admittedly, is a fairly enjoyable ridge. Or at least I imagine it would be were it possible to see more then a few metres ahead of you. Seeing a trig point emerging out of the mist on an otherwise barren landscape is quite a spooky experience ‚Äì I felt vaguely akin to one of the monkeys at the start of 2001 ‚Äì A Space Odyssey, surrounding that vast solid pillar inquisitively. But there wasn‚Äôt time to peruse on this for too long, as the evening was drawing in and we had a date to keep in Ullapool.

item.title: Buachaille Etive Mor
item.description: Brucey‚Äôs protective, cautionary side does not show itself often, but it‚Äôs undoubtedly there. One of his female housemates once commented that ‚Äúhe really looks after us in the flat, he‚Äôs like the Dad of the house!‚Äù and I can now sort of imagine how this is true. I get the feeling people are likely to misrepresent him as being some kind of mad Scottish loony, especially when up on the munros, risking his life for the sake of a quick bag or a bit of a laugh, but I‚Äôm beginning to think that under the ‚Äúker-azy‚Äù exterior, he‚Äôs alarmingly sensible. Posit: we‚Äôre at the bottom of a gorgeous snow-covered gully on Buachaille Etive Mor, and I‚Äôm gagging to don some crampons (lent to me by the man himself), and get going. But Brucey has other ideas:

item.title: Drunkenness and Debauchery in Rural Scotland
item.description: I still can‚Äôt quite believe that we all woke up at 6:30am on a Saturday. ¬†But evidently it happened. ¬†The journey up to Killin was fantastic, truly amazing. ¬†All the floods, cloud, and rain had been left behind in England ‚Äì we had clear open skies and sunny snow-topped peaks. ¬†Bruce quickly ran out of superlatives, and decided to start inventing more, declaring this to be a ‚Äòriptastic‚Äô day. ¬†We had to park up occasionally during the journey to take more photos, the scenery was just so fine.

item.title: Bridge Of Orchy
item.description:
Day Five ‚Äì Beinn Dorain (3,530ft, 1,076m), Beinn An Dothaidh (3,287 ft, 1,002m)

More rain. Can you spot a pattern, dear reader? So we sped over to the western highlands and bagged a couple of munros near Bridge of Orchy, close to our rendezvous with Bruce. I actually quite enjoyed myself, but don‚Äôt tell anybody‚Ä¶

item.title: The Transitional Nineties
item.description:
Day Three ‚Äì Beinn A‚ÄôChaorainn (3,550ft / 1,082m), Beinn Bhreac (3,054ft / 931m).

On which it rained a lot. ¬†Lots of walking across boggy marshy stuff sprinkled with deer and sheep crap. ¬†Another metaphor for life, then.

I‚Äôve never been so glad to see Richard‚Äôs Volvo, and I‚Äôve don‚Äôt remember ever doing anything so exhausting. ¬†Thankfully we‚Äôd already decided that Thursday would be a rest day.

item.title: A Night Under The Stars
item.description:
Day Two ‚Äì Carn A‚ÄôMhaim (3,402ft / 1,037m), Ben Macdui (4,295ft / 1,309m).

I‚Äôm really not fit enough for this lark. ¬†As Rich later said, ‚ÄúNel has invented a pace between stop and walk.‚Äù ¬†But at least I give it a go and get away from the PC once in a while. ¬†Can‚Äôt get much further away from it than Ben Macdui ‚Äì just a shame we didn‚Äôt reach the summit until almost dusk. ¬†Oopsy. ¬†By the time we got to the bothy it was pitch darkness, and the bothy was full of people who showed no intentions of squeezing up. ¬†So after some chicken soup and bread (supplementing the two Mars Bars we had already eaten that day ‚Äì bloaters or what?) we got into sleeping bags and survival bags for a rather damp night‚Äôs sleep. ¬†The first time I‚Äôve ever worn a woolley hat while sleeping, and hopefully the last. ¬†Oh well, at least it didn‚Äôt rain.

item.title: The Cairnwell
item.description:
Does anybody else think Savage Garden sound like Spandau Ballet? ¬†Sorry, just had to get that off my chest‚Ä¶

Day one of the holiday proper, then. ¬†Irn Bru and Double BK Cheeseburger for breakfast, a quick jaunt into the city, and then we‚Äôre off. ¬†We didn‚Äôt reach the highlands until the afternoon, so decided just to bag a few teeny munros which are adjacent to a 2,000ft high road! ¬†Namely Carn Aosda (3,008ft / 917m), Carn A‚ÄôGheoidh (3,199ft / 975m) and The Cairnwell (3,061ft / 933m).

item.title: Schiehallion
item.description: Travelling Northwards on a weekday when others are working is a wonderfully liberating feeling, especially when you‚Äôre heading for Scotland. ¬†This time I was almost glad to see the signal lights on my mobile phone quietly extinguish. ¬†The journey was pretty good ‚Äì we hadn‚Äôt seen Bruce for about a year, as he‚Äôd been off seeing the world for the past nine months. ¬†This gave us the opportunity to fill him in on nine months of pop culture, which seemed to boil down to:

item.title: Meall a‚ÄôChrasgaidh
item.description:
Good Friday, 10th April 1998.

While the Good Friday Agreement was being signed in Belfast, I was reluctantly plodding up my first ever Munro, the dreary featureless lump that is Meall a‚ÄôChrasgaidh.

Only the view across to the mighty An Teallach served to convince me that it was perhaps worth giving this hillwalking lark another try.
